column3: Fowl can mean both a type of bird and can be used to describe something unpleasant or bad.
column4: The farmer raised several species of fowl on his property.
column5: The conduct during the game was deemed fowl by the spectators.

column3: Jam can refer to a fruit spread and also to a situation where something is stuck or packed in tightly.
column4: I spread some jam on my toast for breakfast.
column5: The traffic jam caused us to arrive late to the concert.

column3: While pizza typically refers to the food item, the joke plays off the idea of it being a living entity based on the jokes context, which is inappropriate and offensive.
column4: I ordered a pepperoni pizza for dinner last night.
column5: The chef skillfully tossed the pizza dough into the air.

column3: Flemmy describes something related to phlegm, often used in a gross or humorous context, but phlegm itself can refer to a bodily fluid.
column4: He felt quite flemmy after catching that cold.
column5: The presence of phlegm often indicates an underlying infection.

column3: Pilot can mean a person operating an aircraft, but in other contexts, it can refer to an introductory episode or project (as in television).
column4: The experienced pilot flew the aircraft through rough weather.
column5: The pilot episode of the show garnered much attention from the audience.
